head.title: Photochemically Induced Water Harvesting in Metal–Organic Framework | ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering

meta.content: Photochemically Induced Water Harvesting in Metal–Organic Framework

Harvesting water from air is one of the key environmental related issues facing humanity in recent years. In this study, we demonstrate that tha Ni-IRMOF74-III metal–organic framework structure attached with azopyridine molecules can potentially undergo photochemically induced cis/trans transition, leading to significant enhancement in the H2O working capacity. Specifically, grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations indicate an ultrahigh 0.20 kg kg–1 of H2O working capacity at 25 °C adsorption and 65 °C desorption conditions. More importantly, given that the cis/trans switching is predominantly responsible for the discrepancy in the H2O uptake, even in the mild condition of 35 °C desorption (10 °C diurnal temperature swing), the H2O working capacity is still very high at 0.18 kg kg–1. Our theoretical findings provide a blueprint to design the next generation water harvesting materials that can operate in natural conditions to expand its applicability in different regions around the world.

div.p:
Harvesting water from air is one of the key environmental related issues facing humanity in recent years. In this study, we demonstrate that tha Ni-IRMOF74-III metal–organic framework structure attached with azopyridine molecules can potentially undergo photochemically induced cis/trans transition, leading to significant enhancement in the H
2
O working capacity. Specifically, grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations indicate an ultrahigh 0.20 kg kg
–1
of H
2
O working capacity at 25 °C adsorption and 65 °C desorption conditions. More importantly, given that the cis/trans switching is predominantly responsible for the discrepancy in the H
2
O uptake, even in the mild condition of 35 °C desorption (10 °C diurnal temperature swing), the H
2
O working capacity is still very high at 0.18 kg kg
–1
. Our theoretical findings provide a blueprint to design the next generation water harvesting materials that can operate in natural conditions to expand its applicability in different regions around the world.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

span.p: Using computational simulations, inclusion of azopyridine in Ni-IRMOF74-III showed high water harvesting, even in very small diurnal temperature swing conditions.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Water scarcity is one of the key issues facing humanity in the 21st century.
(1−5)
Including all of the glaciers, stored groundwater, and fractions of lakes and rivers, only 2.5% of all water on earth is fresh water.
(6,7)
Given that ocean water (96.5% of all water) contains salt, most of the water problem thus far has been focused on separating salt from seawater via desalination.
(8−11)
Although desalination process is simple in terms of producing relatively fresh water, it requires distribution infrastructure facilities, which lead to large prepayment capital costs.
(12,13)
Moreover, many countries with water stress are surrounded by land, and thus require alternative ways to access fresh drinking water.

One way to produce water is to capture it directly from the earth’s atmosphere. The humidity in the atmosphere takes on forms of vapor and droplets, and comprises about 10% of all other freshwater resources.
(14−18)
Until now, solid adsorbents such as silica gel and zeolites were used as atmospheric water generators (AWG) to soak up the water from air.
(19−21)
However, these materials have relatively high water affinity, leading to low working capacity and high regeneration costs.
(22)
More recently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been studied as potential candidates for water harvesting, where the process uses a diurnal temperature swing to adsorb and to desorb water from the MOFs.
(23−26)
In particular, Kim et al.
(23)
demonstrated that MOF-801 can produce 100 g of water per kilogram in a single day-and-night cycle using natural sunlight. As a follow-up work, the same group synthesized a composite material with aluminum based MOF-303 and graphite, which reported to the best of our knowledge, the highest water working capacity in MOFs.
(25)
In all of the experiments, the MOFs themselves remained structurally the same throughout the process with operation coming from varying adsorption/desorption curves.

One interesting alternative materials design is to identify ways in which the porous materials themselves can undergo reversible structural modification during the temperature swing process. Previously, Park et al.
(27)
synthesized a MOF functionalized with azobenzene to photochemically switch the linkers (cis/trans configurations) and to subsequently adsorb/desorb CO
2
from the host material. Inspired by this idea, we built a model system of azopyridine molecules inserted inside the Ni-IRMOF-74-III MOF structure (designated as azopyridine-IRMOF-74-III), where the open metal site would serve as an attractive binding site for the azopyridine, which can switch from cis to trans (and vice versa) due to the sunlight (
Figure
1
). Nickel was chosen as the metal as it has the highest water stability among the M-MOF-74 structures.
(28)
Our computational model indicated that the pore sizes of Ni-IRMOF-74-I and Ni-IRMOF-74-II were too small to fit the azopyridine molecules, and as such, the larger Ni-IRMOF-74-III structure was selected.
(29)

div.p: Figure 1. DFT optimized configurations of six azopyridines inserted in the Ni-IRMOF74-III structure. Trans-to-cis isomerization of the azopyridine can be induced by the UV irradiation during day time and the cis-to-trans isomerization by visible light at night time.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Optimization of Ni-IRMOF-74-III structures and the small molecule (i.e., azopyridine, and H
2
O) binding energy calculations were conducted using the first-principles calculations through the density functional theory (DFT) as implemented by the plane-wave pseudopotential approach in Quantum Espresso.
(30)
We used the second version of a van der Waals dispersion-corrected density functional (vdW-DF2).
(31)
Ultrasoft pseudopotentials were used for GGA and vdW-DF2 calculations. The kinetic energy and charge density planewave cutoff were set to 30 and 240 Ry, respectively. 2 × 2 × 2 k-point mesh was used for Brillouin zone sampling in the reciprocal space. The DFT adsorption energies of an individual gas molecule inside the MOF were calculated as follows
(1)

) are the total DFT energy of the MOF with the gas molecule adsorbed in the minimum energy configuration, the total energy of the MOF structures, gas molecule in the gas phase, respectively.

Grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations were performed to obtain the adsorption isotherms data.
(32)
The UFF
(33)
was used to model the framework atoms as it has been shown that the UFF can accurately model for various MOFs.
(34)
In this study, we parametrized the H
2
O–metal interaction versus the quantum chemical reference energies. Parameterizing only the H
2
O–metal interaction, while using a generic force field for the remaining interaction. For the water molecule, we used the conventional TIP4P-Ew model.
(35)

For the short-range repulsion term, Lennard-Jones (LJ) potential type 1/
r
12

To enable the description of the azopyridine ligand, UFF
(33)
parameters were used, and the partial point charges obtained from the DFT calculations. DFT calculations performed using a hybrid generalized gradient approximation with the B3LYP functional,
(36)
implemented in the GAUSSIAN 09 program (G09)
(37)
as the B3LYP have demonstrated to show accurate geometry optimization results.
(38)
The 3-21G basis-set is used to describe all of the electrons in the system.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
To demonstrate the feasibility of such a construct, a single azopyridine molecule was attached to the metal site of the Ni-IRMOF74-III structure, and its DFT binding energy was computed to be −114.1 kJ/mol for the trans and −115.6 kJ/mol for the cis configuration (binding configurations of the azopyridine (
Figure S1
). These values were deemed to be sufficiently large to keep the azopyridine bounded to the metal site as previous work regarding EDA attached to the Ni-MOF-74 structure showed a similar binding energy value (i.e., −125 kJ/mol), and the authors indicated that the EDA stayed in tact.
(39)
Next, with the Ni-IRMOF-74-III fully occupied with azopyridines at each metal site, the H
2
O binding energies were calculated to be −42.2 kJ/mol for the trans and −34.2 kJ/mol for the cis configurations (see
Figure S2
in Section 1). With the inclusion of the azopyridines and the subsequent absence of the open metal sites, the H
2
O binding energy became much weaker compared to that of −60 kJ/mol computed in the bare Ni-IRMOF-74-III structure. From these DFT data, the classical force field parameters were fitted to reproduce the H
2
O DFT energy values. Moreover, the force fields we have for H
2
O in Ni-MOF-74 agreed well with the experimental data
(40)
as shown in the Supporting Information (
Table S1
,
Figure S3
).

Using the optimized azopyridine configurations (i.e., one azopyridine molecule per metal site) from the DFT simulations, classical molecular dynamics simulations were conducted at 300 K to visualize the thermal movements of the azopyridine molecules (see Section 2 in the
Supporting Information
). It turns out that the azopyridine molecules were for the most part immobile, and with this information at hand, classical grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations were conducted under the fixed framework assumption (for both the azopyridine molecules and the MOF) to obtain the H
2
O isotherms at various temperatures (25 °C, 35 °C, 45 and 65 °C) up to 2.5 kPa for both the cis and the trans configurations (
Figure
2
). Our computational results indicate that the trans (circle symbol in
Figure
2
) to cis (triangle symbol in
Figure
2
) isomerization of the azopyridine lead to significant reduction in the uptakes, which is responsible for the large H
2
O working capacity (i.e., difference between adsorption and desorption uptakes at the same pressure) compared to the nonisomerization case.

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) H
2
O adsorption isotherms of azopyridine-IRMOF74-III at 25, 35, 45 and 65 °C represented by blue, green, yellow and red, respectively. The dashed line indicates the adsorption/desorption pressure for the temperature swing process. (b) H
2
O working capacity in azopyridine-IRMOF74-III with different desorption temperatures between isomerization (cis to trans) and nonisomerization (trans to trans) cases.

div.div:
During night time (25 °C) before the UV exposure, azopyridine-IRMOF74-III adsorbed 0.33 kg kg
–1
H
2
O at 2 kPa. In contrast, during daytime (65 °C), after UV exposure, trans-to-cis isomerization can occur in the azopyridine-IRMOF74-III and the H
2
O adsorption amount decreased to 0.13 kg kg
–1
at 2 kPa, leading to the working capacity of 0.20 kg kg
–1
. This theoretical value is higher than that of the MOF-303/graphite structure,
(25)
which was reported to be 0.175 kg kg
–1
, albeit we assume ideal conditions (e.g., no defects). It turns out that the working capacity decreases significantly to only 0.07 kg kg
–1
when the trans configuration is maintained for both the adsorption and the desorption. It is noteworthy to mention that the H
2
O working capacity shows only slight reduction upon reducing the desorption temperature (
Figure
2
b). In particular, while setting the adsorption temperature constant at 25 °C, the H
2
O working capacity values are obtained to be 0.19, 0.18 and 0.15 kg kg
–1
, respectively at desorption temperatures of 45, 35 and 25 °C. These results indicate that the azopyridine-IRMOF74-III can be deployed as promising water harvesting material not only in regions with extreme diurnal temperature swings but also in majority of the regions around the world with small diurnal temperature differences.

To understand the mechanism behind this huge discrepancy between cis/trans configurations in terms of the H
2
O uptakes, the adsorption isotherms were obtained up to 100 kPa to obtain the H
2
O saturation uptake (
Figure
3
a). It can be seen from the isotherms that at higher pressures, the trans and the cis H
2
O uptakes converge to one another indicating that the total amount of free pore volume for H
2
O remains the same for both cases. Next, the H
2
O–Ni force field parameter was tuned to equate the H
2
O binding energy values in the cis (−34.2 kJ/mol to −42 kJ/mol) and the trans (−42.2 kJ/mol) configurations (see
Supporting Information Section 3
). With the new force field parameter for the cis case, the adsorption isotherms were again obtained, and the resulting change made negligible differences in the isotherms (see
Figure S7
). As such, we came to the conclusion that the effect of the trans/cis configuration comes largely from the pore partitioning that occurs due to the switching. In the cis case, the structure have relatively large single pore located in the center of the MOF channel, which leads to suboptimal redistribution of the pores in terms of H
2
O uptake at lower pressures. Similar results have been shown in our previous study
(41,42)
where a pore space partition strategy was employed through a symmetry-matching regulated ligand insertion within the MOF-74 structures. As such, the snapshot of H
2
O molecules in our simulations show higher uptake in the trans case as opposed to cis case due to more available surface area in the former (
Figure
3
b). It is noteworthy to mention that looking at even larger pores in the family of IRMOF74 structures (e.g., IRMOF74-III, IRMOF74-IV, IRMOF74-V, IRMOF74-VI), the discrepancy between the size of the center pores between the trans and the cis configurations start to vanish and as such, we expect there to be poor performance for larger sized IRMOF-74 structures (
Figure S8
).

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) H
2
O adsorption isotherm in azopyridine-IRMOF74-III at 25 °C. (b) Snapshot of H
2
O adsorption in both the trans and the cis azopyridine-IRMOF74-III at 2 kPa (taken from molecular simulations). To better illustrate the snapshot, the single pore channel was zoomed in and exterior atoms were omitted.

div.div:
Next, to ensure that our simulation results are not sensitive to the DFT binding energy data, the classical force field parameters were artificially changed such that the binding energies of the trans configuration ranged from −32.2 kJ/mol (−20% of the original value) to −52.7 kJ/mol (+20% of the original value). One can see from
Table S2
that due to cancellations the H
2
O working capacity at 25 °C adsorption and 25 °C desorption remains almost the same. Moreover, given that the uptakes are near the saturation region of the isotherms, it becomes less sensitive to the binding energy values. This indicates that our numerical results are robust to potential errors in the DFT simulations.

Finally, it is conceivable that during experimental synthesis of this material, it might be difficult to populate one azopyridine/metal site for all the metal sites in the MOF. As such, the simulations were conducted with smaller number of azopyridines to see the effect of its density on the H
2
O working capacity. In
Figure
4
, the H
2
O working capacity was plotted as a function of density of azopyridines in the IRMOF74-III structure for different desorption temperatures (see
Figures S9, S10 and S11
for individual H
2
O isotherm data).
Figure
4
shows a clear trend that the H
2
O working capacity suffers upon decreasing the density of the azopyridines. Moreover, the temperature swing plays a bigger role in maintaining the high working capacity for smaller density of azopyridines as can be seen from the larger discrepancies in the working capacity ranging from 25 °C desorption and 65 °C desorption in the case for 0.5 azopyridine/metal site compared to the case for 1 azopyridine/metal site. These results taken together illustrates the importance of constructing the material with maximum density of azopyridines.

div.p:
Figure 4. H
2
O working capacity (trans to cis isomerization) versus number of inserted azopyridines/metal site in Ni-IRMOF74-III.

div.div:
In this work, we used the concept of photochemically induced water harvesting to optimize the H
2
O water working capacity in a system that consists of azopyridines in Ni-IRMOF74-III. Using both DFT and classical Monte Carlo simulations, we revealed that inclusion of azopyridine in Ni-IRMOF74-III leads to high water harvesting, among the reported MOFs for water harvesting, at even very small temperature swing conditions. As such, our work can serve as a blueprint for experimentalists interested in designing the optimal water harvesting material system and our work demonstrates the importance of using rational computational materials design for energy/environmental applications.

Efficient technologies for worldwide clean water supply
Macedonio, F.; Drioli, E.; Gusev, A. A.; Bardow, A.; Semiat, R.; Kurihara, M.
Chemical Engineering and Processing

0255-2701

(
Elsevier B.V.
)
A review. An overview of the problems assocd. with worldwide water shortage problem and of the increasing public participation and awareness to this problem is presented in this work. The existing water treatment processes and their importance in terms of amt., quality and cost of water produced as well as their environmental impact are illustrated. That includes a survey of the current desalination techniques in use and an overview of possible future technologies, aiming at solving different water issues. The technol. developments and challenges together with new possible prodn. modes for the future urban water planning are also presented. Finally, routes towards a modern and advanced city planning in a cheaper and more sustainable way based on a more rational use of water, by supplying water of different quality to the final users according to their requirements, as well as the employment of process intensification principles are discussed.

Freshwater scarcity is increasingly perceived as a global systemic risk. Previous global water scarcity assessments, measuring water scarcity annually, have underestimated experienced water scarcity by failing to capture the seasonal fluctuations in water consumption and availability. We assess blue water scarcity globally at a high spatial resoln. on a monthly basis. We find that two-thirds of the global population (4.0 billion people) live under conditions of severe water scarcity at least 1 mo of the year. Nearly half of those people live in India and China. Half a billion people in the world face severe water scarcity all year round. Putting caps to water consumption by river basin, increasing water-use efficiencies, and better sharing of the limited freshwater resources will be key in reducing the threat posed by water scarcity on biodiversity and human welfare.

A review. Global energy consumption is projected to increase, even in the face of substantial declines in energy intensity, ≥2-fold by mid century relative to the present because of population and economic growth. This demand could be met, in principle, from fossil energy resources, particularly coal. However, the cumulative nature of CO2 emissions in the atm. demands that holding atm. CO2 levels to even twice their pre-anthropogenic values by mid century will require invention, development, and deployment of schemes for C-neutral energy prodn. on a scale commensurate with, or larger than, the entire present-day energy supply from all sources combined. Among renewable energy resources, solar energy is by far the largest exploitable resource, providing more energy in 1 h to the earth than all of the energy consumed by humans in an entire year. In view of the intermittence of insolation, if solar energy is to be a major primary energy source, it must be stored and dispatched on demand to the end user. An esp. attractive approach is to store solar-converted energy as chem. bonds, i.e., in a photosynthetic process at a year-round av. efficiency significantly higher than current plants or algae, to reduce land-area requirements. Scientific challenges involved with this process include schemes to capture and convert solar energy and then store the energy as chem. bonds, producing O from H2O and a reduced fuel such as H, methane, MeOH, or other hydrocarbon species.

A review. The worldwide need for fresh water requires more and more plants for the treatment of nonconventional water sources. During the last decades, seawater has become an important source of fresh water in many arid regions. The traditional desalination processes [reverse osmosis (RO), multi stage flash (MSF), multi effect distn. (MED), electrodialysis (ED)] have evolved to reliable and established processes; current research focuses on process improvements in view of a lower cost and a more environmentally friendly operation. This paper provides an overview of recent process improvements in seawater desalination using RO, MSF, MED and ED. Important topics that are discussed include the use of alternative energy sources (wind energy, solar energy, nuclear energy) for RO or distn. processes, and the impact of the different desalination process on the environment; the implementation of hybrid processes in seawater desalination; pretreatment of desalination plants by pressure driven membrane processes (microfiltration, ultrafiltration and nanofiltration) compared to chem. pretreatment; new materials to prevent corrosion in distn. processes; and the prevention of fouling in reverse osmosis units. These improvements contribute to the cost effectiveness of the desalination process, and ensure a sustainable prodn. of drinking water on long terms in regions with limited reserves of fresh water.

A review. While the importance of desalination was increasing steadily over the past decades, views on the merits of desalination among water professionals differ. Some portray desalination as a panacea for much of the world's water woes. Others perceive desalination very neg. because of its alleged high costs, energy intensity, and environmental impacts. While none of these extreme positions appears to be justified, it remains even more necessary to gain an objective understanding of the real stakes in desalination in the context of integrated water resources management. The World Bank has undertaken a regional study that aims at improving the understanding of desalination within the Bank and among some of its clients in the Middle East, North Africa, and Central Asia. It also tries to clarify the conditions under which desalination can help in reaching the United Nation's Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) for water supply and sanitation. The study, which was funded by the Bank-Netherlands Water Partnership, includes case studies of Algeria, Cyprus, Jordan, Malta, Tunisia, and Uzbekistan. A key conclusion of the study is that desalination alone cannot deliver the promise of improved water supply. The ability to make the best use of desalination is subject to a series of wider water sector related conditions. In some countries weak water utilities, politically detd. low tariffs, high water losses, and poor sector policies mean that desalinated water, just like any other new source of bulk water, may not be used wisely or that plants are at risk of falling into disrepair. Under these conditions, there is a risk that substantial amts. of money are going to be used inefficiently, and that desalination cannot deliver its promise to alleviate water scarcity and to contribute to the achievement of the MDGs. It may be preferable not to engage on desalination on a large scale unless the underlying weaknesses of the water sector are being seriously addressed. A program to address these weaknesses should include a redn. of non-revenue water; appropriate cost recovery; limited use of targeted subsidies; sound investment planning; integrated water resources management; proper environmental impact assessments; and capacity building in desalination as well as in water resources management and utility management. In any case, desalination should remain the last resort, and should only be applied after having carefully considered cheaper alternatives in terms of supply and demand management. A second conclusion is that the private sector can play a useful and important role in funding and operating desalination plants, but only if the above conditions are met. If these conditions are absent, there is a risk that excessive investments in desalination become a drain to the national budget, either directly under public financing or indirectly through implicit or explicit guarantees under private financing. A third conclusion is that desalination technol. itself has evolved substantially, making it significantly cheaper, more reliable, less energy-intensive, and more environmentally friendly than it was a few decades ago. This is esp. true for reverse osmosis, which is gaining a large share of the market outside the Gulf countries which continue to use mainly distn. technologies.

A review. As water resources are rapidly being exhausted, more and more interest is paid to the desalination of seawater and brackish water concns. Today, current desalination methods require large amts. of energy which is costly both in environmental pollution and in money terms. Many studies of water desalination costs appear regularly in water desalination and renewable energy related publications. Cost ests. seem to be very much site specific and the cost per cubic meter ranges from installation to installation. This variability exists because the water cost depends upon many factors, unique in each case, most important of which are the desalination method, the level of feed water salinity, the energy source, the capacity of the desalting plant, and other site related factors. This paper attempts the taxonomy of a large no. of related publications, classified in a systematic method and format, to allow meaningful comparisons and facilitate the derivation of useful conclusions.

Harvesting water from humid air via dewing can provide a viable soln. to a water shortage problem where liq.-phase water is not available. We exptl. quantify the effects of wettability and geometry of the condensation substrate on the water harvest efficiency. Uniformly hydrophilic surfaces are found to exhibit higher rates of water condensation and collection than surfaces with lower wettability. This is in contrast to a fog basking method where the most efficient surface consists of hydrophilic islands surrounded by hydrophobic background. A thin drainage path in the lower portion of the condensation substrate is revealed to greatly enhance the water collection efficiency. The optimal surface conditions found in this work can be used to design a practical device that harvests water as its biol. counterpart, a green tree frog, Litoria caerulea, does during the dry season in tropical northern Australia.

The collection of fog water is a simple and sustainable technology to obtain fresh water for afforestation, gardening, and as a drinking water source for human and animal consumption. In regions where fresh water is sparse and fog frequently occurs, it is feasible to set up a passive mesh system for fog water collection. The mesh is directly exposed to the atmosphere, and the foggy air is pushed through the mesh by the wind. Fog droplets are deposited on the mesh, combine to form larger droplets, and run down passing into a storage tank. Fog water collection rates vary dramatically from site to site but yearly averages from 3 to 10 l m(-2) of mesh per day are typical of operational projects. The scope of this article is to review fog collection projects worldwide, to analyze factors of success, and to evaluate the prospects of this technology.

Fog represents a large untapped source of potable water, esp. in arid climates. Numerous plants and animals use textural and chem. features on their surfaces to harvest this precious resource. In this work, we investigate the influence of the surface wettability characteristics, length scale, and weave d. on the fog-harvesting capability of woven meshes. We develop a combined hydrodynamic and surface wettability model to predict the overall fog-collection efficiency of the meshes and cast the findings in the form of a design chart. Two limiting surface wettability constraints govern the re-entrainment of collected droplets and clogging of mesh openings. Appropriate tuning of the wetting characteristics of the surfaces, reducing the wire radii, and optimizing the wire spacing all lead to more efficient fog collection. We use a family of coated meshes with a directed stream of fog droplets to simulate a natural foggy environment and demonstrate a five-fold enhancement in the fog-collecting efficiency of a conventional polyolefin mesh. The design rules developed in this work can be applied to select a mesh surface with optimal topog. and wetting characteristics to harvest enhanced water fluxes over a wide range of natural convected fog environments.

A new highly-efficient water-selective composite adsorbent for solar-driven fresh water prodn. from the atm. air is presented. Both can be driven by the solar collector at 70-80 °C temp. 0.32 kg water is collected in concept machine with roll-up shape of 2.25 kg ACF-CaCl2 sorbent. 9 kg water is collected with 4 m2 solar collector area by the improved semi-open type device, and corrugated and flat sorbents is manufd. to pack 40.8 kg consolidated ACF-LiCl sorbents in 0.4 × 0.4 × 0.6 m bed.

In this paper the exptl. results of a lab.-scale chilling module working with the composite sorbent SWS-1L (mesoporous silica gel impregnated with CaCl2) are presented. The interesting sorption properties of this material yield a high COP = 0.6 that gives a promising alternative to the common zeolite or silica gel for application in solid sorption units driven by low temp. heat (T ≤ 100°). The measured low specific power of the device is a result of not optimized geometry of the adsorber and of the pelletized shape of the adsorbent. Heat transfer optimization is currently under progress to increase the specific power. The exptl. results are compared with those of a mathematic model able to describe the dynamic behavior of the system. The model is used to study the effect of the main operating parameters on the system performance.

Atm. water is a resource equiv. to -10% of all fresh water in lakes on Earth. However, an efficient process for capturing and delivering water from air, esp. at low humidity levels (down to 20%), has not been developed. We report the design and demonstration of a device based on a porous metal-org. framework {M0F-801, [Zr604(0H)4(fumarate)6]} that captures water from the atm. at ambient conditions by using low-grade heat from natural sunlight at a flux of less than 1 sun (1 kW per square meter). This device is capable of harvesting 2.8 L of water per kg of MOF daily at relative humidity levels as low as 20% and requires no addnl. input of energy.

Kim, Jin Kyung; Kim, Yi Sak; Lee, Hye-Mi; Jin, Hyo Sun; Neupane, Chiranjivi; Kim, Sup; Lee, Sang-Hee; Min, Jung-Joon; Sasai, Miwa; Jeong, Jae-Ho; Choe, Seong-Kyu; Kim, Jin-Man; Yamamoto, Masahiro; Choy, Hyon E.; Park, Jin Bong; Jo, Eun-Kyeong

Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is the principal inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain; however, the roles of GABA in antimicrobial host defenses are largely unknown. Here we demonstrate that GABAergic activation enhances antimicrobial responses against intracellular bacterial infection. Intracellular bacterial infection decreases GABA levels in vitro in macrophages and in vivo in sera. Treatment of macrophages with GABA or GABAergic drugs promotes autophagy activation, enhances phagosomal maturation and antimicrobial responses against mycobacterial infection. In macrophages, the GABAergic defense is mediated via macrophage type A GABA receptor (GABAAR), intracellular calcium release, and the GABA type A receptor-assocd. protein-like 1 (GABARAPL1; an Atg8 homolog). Finally, GABAergic inhibition increases bacterial loads in mice and zebrafish in vivo, suggesting that the GABAergic defense plays an essential function in metazoan host defenses. Our study identified a previously unappreciated role for GABAergic signaling in linking antibacterial autophagy to enhance host innate defense against intracellular bacterial infection.

A series of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) M2(dobpdc) (M = Mn, Co, Ni, Zn; H4dobpdc = 4,4'-dihydroxy-1,1'-biphenyl-3,3'-dicarboxylic acid), with a highly dense arrangement of open metal sites along hexagonal channels were prepd. by microwave-assisted or simple solvothermal reactions. The activated materials were structurally expanded when guest mols. including CO2 were introduced into the pores. The Lewis acidity of the open metal sites varied in the order Mn < Co < Ni > Zn, as confirmed by C=O stretching bands in the IR spectra, which are related to the CO2 adsorption enthalpy. DFT calcns. revealed that the high CO2 binding affinity of transition-metal-based M2(dobpdc) is primarily attributable to the favorable charge transfer from CO2 (oxygen lone pair acting as a Lewis base) to the open metal sites (Lewis acid), while electrostatic effects, the underlying factor responsible for the particular order of binding strength obsd. across different transition metals, also play a role. The framework stability against water coincides with the order of Lewis acidity. In this series of MOFs, the structural stability of Ni2(dobpdc) is exceptional; it endured in water vapor, liq. water, and in refluxing water for one month, and the solid remained intact on exposure to solns. of pH 2-13. The DFT calcns. also support the exptl. finding that Ni2(dobpdc) has higher chem. stability than the other frameworks.

The authors report a strategy to expand the pore aperture of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) into a previously unattained size regime (>32 Å). Specifically, the systematic expansion of a known MOF structure, MOF-74, from its original link of one phenylene ring (I) to two, three, four, five, six, seven, nine, and eleven (II to XI, resp.), afforded an isoreticular series of Mg- or Zn-contg. MOF-74 structures (termed IRMOF-74-I to -XI) with pore apertures ranging from 14 to 98 Å. All members of this series have noninterpenetrating structures and exhibit robust architectures, as evidenced by their permanent porosity and high thermal stability (up to 300°). The pore apertures of an oligoethylene glycol-functionalized IRMOF-74-VII and IRMOF-74-IX are large enough for natural proteins to enter the pores.

Giannozzi Paolo; Baroni Stefano; Bonini Nicola; Calandra Matteo; Car Roberto; Cavazzoni Carlo; Ceresoli Davide; Chiarotti Guido L; Cococcioni Matteo; Dabo Ismaila; Dal Corso Andrea; de Gironcoli Stefano; Fabris Stefano; Fratesi Guido; Gebauer Ralph; Gerstmann Uwe; Gougoussis Christos; Kokalj Anton; Lazzeri Michele; Martin-Samos Layla; Marzari Nicola; Mauri Francesco; Mazzarello Riccardo; Paolini Stefano; Pasquarello Alfredo; Paulatto Lorenzo; Sbraccia Carlo; Scandolo Sandro; Sclauzero Gabriele; Seitsonen Ari P; Smogunov Alexander; Umari Paolo; Wentzcovitch Renata M

QUANTUM ESPRESSO is an integrated suite of computer codes for electronic-structure calculations and materials modeling, based on density-functional theory, plane waves, and pseudopotentials (norm-conserving, ultrasoft, and projector-augmented wave). The acronym ESPRESSO stands for opEn Source Package for Research in Electronic Structure, Simulation, and Optimization. It is freely available to researchers around the world under the terms of the GNU General Public License. QUANTUM ESPRESSO builds upon newly-restructured electronic-structure codes that have been developed and tested by some of the original authors of novel electronic-structure algorithms and applied in the last twenty years by some of the leading materials modeling groups worldwide. Innovation and efficiency are still its main focus, with special attention paid to massively parallel architectures, and a great effort being devoted to user friendliness. QUANTUM ESPRESSO is evolving towards a distribution of independent and interoperable codes in the spirit of an open-source project, where researchers active in the field of electronic-structure calculations are encouraged to participate in the project by contributing their own codes or by implementing their own ideas into existing codes.

A new software package, RASPA, for simulating adsorption and diffusion of mols. in flexible nanoporous materials is presented. The code implements the latest state-of-the-art algorithms for mol. dynamics and Monte Carlo (MC) in various ensembles including symplectic/measure-preserving integrators, Ewald summation, configurational-bias MC, continuous fractional component MC, reactive MC and Baker's minimisation. We show example applications of RASPA in computing coexistence properties, adsorption isotherms for single and multiple components, self- and collective diffusivities, reaction systems and visualisation. The software is released under the GNU General Public License.

A re-parameterization of the std. TIP4P water model for use with Ewald techniques is introduced, providing an overall global improvement in water properties relative to several popular nonpolarizable and polarizable water potentials. Using high precision simulations, and careful application of std. anal. corrections, we show that the new TIP4P-Ew potential has a d. max. at ∼1°, and reproduces exptl. bulk-densities and the enthalpy of vaporization, ΔHvap, from -37.5 to 127° at 1 atm with an abs. av. error of less than 1%. Structural properties are in very good agreement with X-ray scattering intensities at temps. between 0 and 77° and dynamical properties such as self-diffusion coeff. are in excellent agreement with expt. Testing of the commonly used hybrid d. functional B3LYP with the 6-31G(d), 6-31G(d,p), and 6-31+G(d,p) basis sets has been carried out for 622 neutral, closed-shell org. compds. contg. the elements C, H, N, and O. The focus is comparison of computed and exptl. heats of formation and isomerization energies. In addn., the effect of an empirical dispersion correction term has been evaluated and found to improve agreement with the exptl. data. For the 622 compds., the mean abs. errors (MAE) in the heats of formation are 3.1, 2.6, 2.7, and 2.4 kcal/mol for B3LYP/6-31G(d), B3LYP/6-31G(d,p), B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p), and B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p) with the dispersion correction. A diverse set of 34 isomerizations highlights specific issues of general interest, such as performance on differences in steric effects, conjugation, and bonding. The corresponding MAEs for the isomerizations are 2.7, 2.4, 2.2, and 1.9 kcal/mol. Improvement is obtained for isomerizations of amines and alcs. when both polarization and diffuse functions are used, but the overstabilization of linear alkanes compared to branched isomers can be relieved only with the dispersion correction. Besides the insights on DFT methods, the study also aimed to quantify the gains in accuracy that can be achieved by replacing energetics from NDO-based semiempirical methods with DFT results. Since the MAEs obtained with the PDDG/PM3 method for the 622 heats of formation and 34 isomerizations are 2.8 and 2.3 kcal/mol, negligible advantage in accuracy for the B3LYP-based methods emerged in the absence of the dispersion corrections.

The main challenge for gas storage and sepn. in nanoporous materials is that many mols. of interest adsorb too weakly to be effectively retained. Instead of synthetically modifying the internal surface structure of the entire bulk-as is typically done to enhance adsorption-here we show that post exposure of a prototypical porous metal-org. framework to ethylenediamine can effectively retain a variety of weakly adsorbing mols. (for example, CO, CO2, SO2, C2H4, NO) inside the materials by forming a monolayer-thick cap at the external surface of microcrystals. Furthermore, this capping mechanism, based on hydrogen bonding as explained by ab initio modeling, opens the door for potential selectivity. For example, water mols. are shown to disrupt the hydrogen-bonded amine network and diffuse through the cap without hindrance and fully displace/release the retained small mols. out of the metal-org. framework at room temp. These findings may provide alternative strategies for gas storage, delivery and sepn.

Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have recently attracted intense research interest because of their permanent porous structures, huge surface areas, and potential applications as novel adsorbents and catalysts. In order to provide a basis for consideration of MOFs for removal of carbon dioxide from gases contg. water vapor, such as flue gas, we have studied adsorption equil. of CO2, H2O vapor, and their mixts. and also rates of CO2 adsorption in two MOFs: HKUST-1 (CuBTC) and Ni/DOBDC (CPO-27-Ni or Ni/MOF-74). The MOFs were synthesized via solvothermal methods, and the as-synthesized products were solvent exchanged and regenerated before expts. Pure component adsorption equil. and CO2/H2O binary adsorption equil. were studied using a volumetric system. The effects of H2O adsorption on CO2 adsorption for both MOF samples were detd., and the results for 5A and NaX zeolites were included for comparison. The hydrothermal stabilities for the two MOFs over the course of repetitive measurements of H2O and CO2/H2O mixt. equil. were also studied. CO2 adsorption rates from helium for the MOF samples were investigated by using a unique concn.-swing frequency response (CSFR) system. Mass transfer into the MOFs is rapid with the controlling resistance found to be macropore diffusion, and rate parameters were established for the mechanism.

Among various class of materials, metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are a most promising candidate for flue gas CO2 capture. In particular, M-MOF-74, where M = different metals, are equipped with open metal sites which can lead to very high CO2 uptake in post-combustion flue gas conditions. However, these structures are known to have poor CO2 capture performance under humid conditions since water mols. strongly bind to the unsatd. metal sites, out-competing CO2. This computational study used a pore space partition strategy via symmetry-matching regulated ligand insertion within the Mg-MOF-74 and Zn-MOF-74 structures to mitigate the water deterioration effect. For Zn-MOF-74, higher selectivity and larger CO2 uptake in binary mixt. conditions were obtained, demonstrating that redn. in MOF pore size is a viable strategy to capture CO2 under humid post-combustion conditions.

Efficient conversion of ethane into valuable materials is important with the availability of new natural gas resources. Recently, metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with open iron sites (i.e., Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74) have been shown to be promising material for catalyzing ethane to ethanol. In this computational study, various size-matching ligands are inserted into the Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74 structure to further optimize this reaction. Our d. functional theory calcns. show that the presence of ligands enhances the binding affinity of the oxygen atoms of N2O to the iron atoms in the framework, thereby leading to an improvement in the oxidizing process. Furthermore, the reaction pathways for the new structures show reduced enthalpy barrier in the rate-detg. step in the oxidn. of ethane reaction cycle compared to the original Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74. These findings provide ways in which the performance of the Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74 can be optimized for next-generation catalysts.

A review. An overview of the problems assocd. with worldwide water shortage problem and of the increasing public participation and awareness to this problem is presented in this work. The existing water treatment processes and their importance in terms of amt., quality and cost of water produced as well as their environmental impact are illustrated. That includes a survey of the current desalination techniques in use and an overview of possible future technologies, aiming at solving different water issues. The technol. developments and challenges together with new possible prodn. modes for the future urban water planning are also presented. Finally, routes towards a modern and advanced city planning in a cheaper and more sustainable way based on a more rational use of water, by supplying water of different quality to the final users according to their requirements, as well as the employment of process intensification principles are discussed.

Freshwater scarcity is increasingly perceived as a global systemic risk. Previous global water scarcity assessments, measuring water scarcity annually, have underestimated experienced water scarcity by failing to capture the seasonal fluctuations in water consumption and availability. We assess blue water scarcity globally at a high spatial resoln. on a monthly basis. We find that two-thirds of the global population (4.0 billion people) live under conditions of severe water scarcity at least 1 mo of the year. Nearly half of those people live in India and China. Half a billion people in the world face severe water scarcity all year round. Putting caps to water consumption by river basin, increasing water-use efficiencies, and better sharing of the limited freshwater resources will be key in reducing the threat posed by water scarcity on biodiversity and human welfare.

A review. Global energy consumption is projected to increase, even in the face of substantial declines in energy intensity, ≥2-fold by mid century relative to the present because of population and economic growth. This demand could be met, in principle, from fossil energy resources, particularly coal. However, the cumulative nature of CO2 emissions in the atm. demands that holding atm. CO2 levels to even twice their pre-anthropogenic values by mid century will require invention, development, and deployment of schemes for C-neutral energy prodn. on a scale commensurate with, or larger than, the entire present-day energy supply from all sources combined. Among renewable energy resources, solar energy is by far the largest exploitable resource, providing more energy in 1 h to the earth than all of the energy consumed by humans in an entire year. In view of the intermittence of insolation, if solar energy is to be a major primary energy source, it must be stored and dispatched on demand to the end user. An esp. attractive approach is to store solar-converted energy as chem. bonds, i.e., in a photosynthetic process at a year-round av. efficiency significantly higher than current plants or algae, to reduce land-area requirements. Scientific challenges involved with this process include schemes to capture and convert solar energy and then store the energy as chem. bonds, producing O from H2O and a reduced fuel such as H, methane, MeOH, or other hydrocarbon species.

A review. The worldwide need for fresh water requires more and more plants for the treatment of nonconventional water sources. During the last decades, seawater has become an important source of fresh water in many arid regions. The traditional desalination processes [reverse osmosis (RO), multi stage flash (MSF), multi effect distn. (MED), electrodialysis (ED)] have evolved to reliable and established processes; current research focuses on process improvements in view of a lower cost and a more environmentally friendly operation. This paper provides an overview of recent process improvements in seawater desalination using RO, MSF, MED and ED. Important topics that are discussed include the use of alternative energy sources (wind energy, solar energy, nuclear energy) for RO or distn. processes, and the impact of the different desalination process on the environment; the implementation of hybrid processes in seawater desalination; pretreatment of desalination plants by pressure driven membrane processes (microfiltration, ultrafiltration and nanofiltration) compared to chem. pretreatment; new materials to prevent corrosion in distn. processes; and the prevention of fouling in reverse osmosis units. These improvements contribute to the cost effectiveness of the desalination process, and ensure a sustainable prodn. of drinking water on long terms in regions with limited reserves of fresh water.

A review. While the importance of desalination was increasing steadily over the past decades, views on the merits of desalination among water professionals differ. Some portray desalination as a panacea for much of the world's water woes. Others perceive desalination very neg. because of its alleged high costs, energy intensity, and environmental impacts. While none of these extreme positions appears to be justified, it remains even more necessary to gain an objective understanding of the real stakes in desalination in the context of integrated water resources management. The World Bank has undertaken a regional study that aims at improving the understanding of desalination within the Bank and among some of its clients in the Middle East, North Africa, and Central Asia. It also tries to clarify the conditions under which desalination can help in reaching the United Nation's Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) for water supply and sanitation. The study, which was funded by the Bank-Netherlands Water Partnership, includes case studies of Algeria, Cyprus, Jordan, Malta, Tunisia, and Uzbekistan. A key conclusion of the study is that desalination alone cannot deliver the promise of improved water supply. The ability to make the best use of desalination is subject to a series of wider water sector related conditions. In some countries weak water utilities, politically detd. low tariffs, high water losses, and poor sector policies mean that desalinated water, just like any other new source of bulk water, may not be used wisely or that plants are at risk of falling into disrepair. Under these conditions, there is a risk that substantial amts. of money are going to be used inefficiently, and that desalination cannot deliver its promise to alleviate water scarcity and to contribute to the achievement of the MDGs. It may be preferable not to engage on desalination on a large scale unless the underlying weaknesses of the water sector are being seriously addressed. A program to address these weaknesses should include a redn. of non-revenue water; appropriate cost recovery; limited use of targeted subsidies; sound investment planning; integrated water resources management; proper environmental impact assessments; and capacity building in desalination as well as in water resources management and utility management. In any case, desalination should remain the last resort, and should only be applied after having carefully considered cheaper alternatives in terms of supply and demand management. A second conclusion is that the private sector can play a useful and important role in funding and operating desalination plants, but only if the above conditions are met. If these conditions are absent, there is a risk that excessive investments in desalination become a drain to the national budget, either directly under public financing or indirectly through implicit or explicit guarantees under private financing. A third conclusion is that desalination technol. itself has evolved substantially, making it significantly cheaper, more reliable, less energy-intensive, and more environmentally friendly than it was a few decades ago. This is esp. true for reverse osmosis, which is gaining a large share of the market outside the Gulf countries which continue to use mainly distn. technologies.

A review. In recent years, numerous large-scale seawater desalination plants were built in water-stressed countries to augment available water resources, and construction of new desalination plants is expected to increase in the near future. Despite major advancements in desalination technologies, seawater desalination is still more energy intensive compared to conventional technologies for the treatment of fresh water. There are also concerns about the potential environmental impacts of large-scale seawater desalination plants. Here, the authors review the possible redns. in energy demand by state-of-the-art seawater desalination technologies, the potential role of advanced materials and innovative technologies in improving performance, and the sustainability of desalination as a technol. soln. to global water shortages.

A review. As water resources are rapidly being exhausted, more and more interest is paid to the desalination of seawater and brackish water concns. Today, current desalination methods require large amts. of energy which is costly both in environmental pollution and in money terms. Many studies of water desalination costs appear regularly in water desalination and renewable energy related publications. Cost ests. seem to be very much site specific and the cost per cubic meter ranges from installation to installation. This variability exists because the water cost depends upon many factors, unique in each case, most important of which are the desalination method, the level of feed water salinity, the energy source, the capacity of the desalting plant, and other site related factors. This paper attempts the taxonomy of a large no. of related publications, classified in a systematic method and format, to allow meaningful comparisons and facilitate the derivation of useful conclusions.

Harvesting water from humid air via dewing can provide a viable soln. to a water shortage problem where liq.-phase water is not available. We exptl. quantify the effects of wettability and geometry of the condensation substrate on the water harvest efficiency. Uniformly hydrophilic surfaces are found to exhibit higher rates of water condensation and collection than surfaces with lower wettability. This is in contrast to a fog basking method where the most efficient surface consists of hydrophilic islands surrounded by hydrophobic background. A thin drainage path in the lower portion of the condensation substrate is revealed to greatly enhance the water collection efficiency. The optimal surface conditions found in this work can be used to design a practical device that harvests water as its biol. counterpart, a green tree frog, Litoria caerulea, does during the dry season in tropical northern Australia.

The collection of fog water is a simple and sustainable technology to obtain fresh water for afforestation, gardening, and as a drinking water source for human and animal consumption. In regions where fresh water is sparse and fog frequently occurs, it is feasible to set up a passive mesh system for fog water collection. The mesh is directly exposed to the atmosphere, and the foggy air is pushed through the mesh by the wind. Fog droplets are deposited on the mesh, combine to form larger droplets, and run down passing into a storage tank. Fog water collection rates vary dramatically from site to site but yearly averages from 3 to 10 l m(-2) of mesh per day are typical of operational projects. The scope of this article is to review fog collection projects worldwide, to analyze factors of success, and to evaluate the prospects of this technology.

Fog represents a large untapped source of potable water, esp. in arid climates. Numerous plants and animals use textural and chem. features on their surfaces to harvest this precious resource. In this work, we investigate the influence of the surface wettability characteristics, length scale, and weave d. on the fog-harvesting capability of woven meshes. We develop a combined hydrodynamic and surface wettability model to predict the overall fog-collection efficiency of the meshes and cast the findings in the form of a design chart. Two limiting surface wettability constraints govern the re-entrainment of collected droplets and clogging of mesh openings. Appropriate tuning of the wetting characteristics of the surfaces, reducing the wire radii, and optimizing the wire spacing all lead to more efficient fog collection. We use a family of coated meshes with a directed stream of fog droplets to simulate a natural foggy environment and demonstrate a five-fold enhancement in the fog-collecting efficiency of a conventional polyolefin mesh. The design rules developed in this work can be applied to select a mesh surface with optimal topog. and wetting characteristics to harvest enhanced water fluxes over a wide range of natural convected fog environments.

Decentralized and remote areas suffer from fresh water shortage. A new sustainable energy technique called "Water Extn. from Atm. Air" is introduced as a beneficial soln. for this problem. This system involves the absorption of water vapor from ambient air during the night time. Then, simultaneous desiccant regeneration and water vapor condensation during the day time will be occurred. In this study, a trapezoidal prism solar collector with four fiberglass sides is designed and constructed. This collector has multi-shelves bed (desiccant carrier) in order to maximize bed surface area inside the collector. Consequently, the absorption and evapn. surfaces are increased. The exptl. work shows the effect of weather conditions in system operation for both day time and night time. The regeneration and absorption processes are discussed for each operation condition. Also, different host materials (cloth and sand) with calcium chloride soln. are investigated. An illustrative comparison between different bed types is demonstrated. The results revealed that the total evapd. water for cloth and sand bed can reach 2.32 and 1.23 slit/days m2 at initial satn. concn. (30%) of cacl2. However, the system efficiency is 29.3 and 17.76% for cloth and sand bed, resp.

A new highly-efficient water-selective composite adsorbent for solar-driven fresh water prodn. from the atm. air is presented. It is synthesized by a patented ultra-large pore cryst. material MCM-41 as host matrixes and Ca chloride as a hygroscopic salt. Exptl. data demonstrate that adsorption capacity of the new composites is as high as 1.75 Kg/Kg dry adsorbent, which is higher than composites synthesized by silica-gel and Ca chloride, and the adsorption rate of the new composites is also found attractive. The desorption characteristics of the new composites are also studied, and it demonstrates that it can desorb >90% of the adsorbed water at lower heating temp. at ∼80°. A solar-driven water prodn. test unit using the new adsorbent is presented and tested. The tests of this unit demonstrated the feasibility of the fresh water prodn. with the daily water productivity >1.2 Kg/m2 solar collector area.

In this paper the exptl. results of a lab.-scale chilling module working with the composite sorbent SWS-1L (mesoporous silica gel impregnated with CaCl2) are presented. The interesting sorption properties of this material yield a high COP = 0.6 that gives a promising alternative to the common zeolite or silica gel for application in solid sorption units driven by low temp. heat (T ≤ 100°). The measured low specific power of the device is a result of not optimized geometry of the adsorber and of the pelletized shape of the adsorbent. Heat transfer optimization is currently under progress to increase the specific power. The exptl. results are compared with those of a mathematic model able to describe the dynamic behavior of the system. The model is used to study the effect of the main operating parameters on the system performance.

Atm. water is a resource equiv. to -10% of all fresh water in lakes on Earth. However, an efficient process for capturing and delivering water from air, esp. at low humidity levels (down to 20%), has not been developed. We report the design and demonstration of a device based on a porous metal-org. framework {M0F-801, [Zr604(0H)4(fumarate)6]} that captures water from the atm. at ambient conditions by using low-grade heat from natural sunlight at a flux of less than 1 sun (1 kW per square meter). Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is the principal inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain; however, the roles of GABA in antimicrobial host defenses are largely unknown. Here we demonstrate that GABAergic activation enhances antimicrobial responses against intracellular bacterial infection. Intracellular bacterial infection decreases GABA levels in vitro in macrophages and in vivo in sera. Treatment of macrophages with GABA or GABAergic drugs promotes autophagy activation, enhances phagosomal maturation and antimicrobial responses against mycobacterial infection. In macrophages, the GABAergic defense is mediated via macrophage type A GABA receptor (GABAAR), intracellular calcium release, and the GABA type A receptor-assocd. protein-like 1 (GABARAPL1; an Atg8 homolog). Finally, GABAergic inhibition increases bacterial loads in mice and zebrafish in vivo, suggesting that the GABAergic defense plays an essential function in metazoan host defenses. Our study identified a previously unappreciated role for GABAergic signaling in linking antibacterial autophagy to enhance host innate defense against intracellular bacterial infection.

The activated materials were structurally expanded when guest mols. including CO2 were introduced into the pores. The Lewis acidity of the open metal sites varied in the order Mn < Co < Ni > Zn, as confirmed by C=O stretching bands in the IR spectra, which are related to the CO2 adsorption enthalpy. DFT calcns. revealed that the high CO2 binding affinity of transition-metal-based M2(dobpdc) is primarily attributable to the favorable charge transfer from CO2 (oxygen lone pair acting as a Lewis base) to the open metal sites (Lewis acid), while electrostatic effects, the underlying factor responsible for the particular order of binding strength obsd. across different transition metals, also play a role. The framework stability against water coincides with the order of Lewis acidity. In this series of MOFs, the structural stability of Ni2(dobpdc) is exceptional; it endured in water vapor, liq. water, and in refluxing water for one month, and the solid remained intact on exposure to solns. of pH 2-13. The DFT calcns. also support the exptl. finding that Ni2(dobpdc) has higher chem. stability than the other frameworks.

The authors report a strategy to expand the pore aperture of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) into a previously unattained size regime (>32 Å). Specifically, the systematic expansion of a known MOF structure, MOF-74, from its original link of one phenylene ring (I) to two, three, four, five, six, seven, nine, and eleven (II to XI, resp.), afforded an isoreticular series of Mg- or Zn-contg. MOF-74 structures (termed IRMOF-74-I to -XI) with pore apertures ranging from 14 to 98 Å. All members of this series have noninterpenetrating structures and exhibit robust architectures, as evidenced by their permanent porosity and high thermal stability (up to 300°). The pore apertures of an oligoethylene glycol-functionalized IRMOF-74-VII and IRMOF-74-IX are large enough for natural proteins to enter the pores.

QUANTUM ESPRESSO: a modular and open-source software project for quantum simulations of materials
Giannozzi Paolo; Baroni Stefano; Bonini Nicola; Calandra Matteo; Car Roberto; Cavazzoni Carlo; Ceresoli Davide; Chiarotti Guido L; Cococcioni Matteo; Dabo Ismaila; Dal Corso Andrea; de Gironcoli Stefano; Fabris Stefano; Fratesi Guido; Gebauer Ralph; Gerstmann Uwe; Gougoussis Christos; Kokalj Anton; Lazzeri Michele; Martin-Samos Layla; Marzari Nicola; Mauri Francesco; Mazzarello Riccardo; Paolini Stefano; Pasquarello Alfredo; Paulatto Lorenzo; Sbraccia Carlo; Scandolo Sandro; Sclauzero Gabriele; Seitsonen Ari P; Smogunov Alexander; Umari Paolo; Wentzcovitch Renata M

QUANTUM ESPRESSO is an integrated suite of computer codes for electronic-structure calculations and materials modeling, based on density-functional theory, plane waves, and pseudopotentials (norm-conserving, ultrasoft, and projector-augmented wave). The acronym ESPRESSO stands for opEn Source Package for Research in Electronic Structure, Simulation, and Optimization. It is freely available to researchers around the world under the terms of the GNU General Public License. QUANTUM ESPRESSO builds upon newly-restructured electronic-structure codes that have been developed and tested by some of the original authors of novel electronic-structure algorithms and applied in the last twenty years by some of the leading materials modeling groups worldwide. Innovation and efficiency are still its main focus, with special attention paid to massively parallel architectures, and a great effort being devoted to user friendliness. QUANTUM ESPRESSO is evolving towards a distribution of independent and interoperable codes in the spirit of an open-source project, where researchers active in the field of electronic-structure calculations are encouraged to participate in the project by contributing their own codes or by implementing their own ideas into existing codes.

A new software package, RASPA, for simulating adsorption and diffusion of mols. in flexible nanoporous materials is presented. The code implements the latest state-of-the-art algorithms for mol. dynamics and Monte Carlo (MC) in various ensembles including symplectic/measure-preserving integrators, Ewald summation, configurational-bias MC, continuous fractional component MC, reactive MC and Baker's minimisation. We show example applications of RASPA in computing coexistence properties, adsorption isotherms for single and multiple components, self- and collective diffusivities, reaction systems and visualisation. The software is released under the GNU General Public License.

A re-parameterization of the std. TIP4P water model for use with Ewald techniques is introduced, providing an overall global improvement in water properties relative to several popular nonpolarizable and polarizable water potentials. Testing of the commonly used hybrid d. functional B3LYP with the 6-31G(d), 6-31G(d,p), and 6-31+G(d,p) basis sets has been carried out for 622 neutral, closed-shell org. compds. contg. the elements C, H, N, and O. The focus is comparison of computed and exptl. heats of formation and isomerization energies. In addn., the effect of an empirical dispersion correction term has been evaluated and found to improve agreement with the exptl. data. For the 622 compds., the mean abs. errors (MAE) in the heats of formation are 3.1, 2.6, 2.7, and 2.4 kcal/mol for B3LYP/6-31G(d), B3LYP/6-31G(d,p), B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p), and B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p) with the dispersion correction. A diverse set of 34 isomerizations highlights specific issues of general interest, such as performance on differences in steric effects, conjugation, and bonding. The corresponding MAEs for the isomerizations are 2.7, 2.4, 2.2, and 1.9 kcal/mol. Improvement is obtained for isomerizations of amines and alcs. when both polarization and diffuse functions are used, but the overstabilization of linear alkanes compared to branched isomers can be relieved only with the dispersion correction. Besides the insights on DFT methods, the study also aimed to quantify the gains in accuracy that can be achieved by replacing energetics from NDO-based semiempirical methods with DFT results. Since the MAEs obtained with the PDDG/PM3 method for the 622 heats of formation and 34 isomerizations are 2.8 and 2.3 kcal/mol, negligible advantage in accuracy for the B3LYP-based methods emerged in the absence of the dispersion corrections.

The main challenge for gas storage and sepn. in nanoporous materials is that many mols. of interest adsorb too weakly to be effectively retained. Instead of synthetically modifying the internal surface structure of the entire bulk-as is typically done to enhance adsorption-here we show that post exposure of a prototypical porous metal-org. framework to ethylenediamine can effectively retain a variety of weakly adsorbing mols. (for example, CO, CO2, SO2, C2H4, NO) inside the materials by forming a monolayer-thick cap at the external surface of microcrystals. Furthermore, this capping mechanism, based on hydrogen bonding as explained by ab initio modeling, opens the door for potential selectivity. For example, water mols. are shown to disrupt the hydrogen-bonded amine network and diffuse through the cap without hindrance and fully displace/release the retained small mols. out of the metal-org. framework at room temp. These findings may provide alternative strategies for gas storage, delivery and sepn.

Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have recently attracted intense research interest because of their permanent porous structures, huge surface areas, and potential applications as novel adsorbents and catalysts. In order to provide a basis for consideration of MOFs for removal of carbon dioxide from gases contg. water vapor, such as flue gas, we have studied adsorption equil. of CO2, H2O vapor, and their mixts. and also rates of CO2 adsorption in two MOFs: HKUST-1 (CuBTC) and Ni/DOBDC (CPO-27-Ni or Ni/MOF-74). The MOFs were synthesized via solvothermal methods, and the as-synthesized products were solvent exchanged and regenerated before expts. Pure component adsorption equil. and CO2/H2O binary adsorption equil. were studied using a volumetric system. The effects of H2O adsorption on CO2 adsorption for both MOF samples were detd., and the results for 5A and NaX zeolites were included for comparison. The hydrothermal stabilities for the two MOFs over the course of repetitive measurements of H2O and CO2/H2O mixt. equil. were also studied. CO2 adsorption rates from helium for the MOF samples were investigated by using a unique concn.-swing frequency response (CSFR) system. Mass transfer into the MOFs is rapid with the controlling resistance found to be macropore diffusion, and rate parameters were established for the mechanism.

Among various class of materials, metal-org. frameworks (MOF) are a most promising candidate for flue gas CO2 capture. In particular, M-MOF-74, where M = different metals, are equipped with open metal sites which can lead to very high CO2 uptake in post-combustion flue gas conditions. However, these structures are known to have poor CO2 capture performance under humid conditions since water mols. strongly bind to the unsatd. metal sites, out-competing CO2. This computational study used a pore space partition strategy via symmetry-matching regulated ligand insertion within the Mg-MOF-74 and Zn-MOF-74 structures to mitigate the water deterioration effect. For Zn-MOF-74, higher selectivity and larger CO2 uptake in binary mixt. conditions were obtained, demonstrating that redn. in MOF pore size is a viable strategy to capture CO2 under humid post-combustion conditions.

Efficient conversion of ethane into valuable materials is important with the availability of new natural gas resources. Recently, metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) with open iron sites (i.e., Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74) have been shown to be promising material for catalyzing ethane to ethanol. In this computational study, various size-matching ligands are inserted into the Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74 structure to further optimize this reaction. Our d. functional theory calcns. show that the presence of ligands enhances the binding affinity of the oxygen atoms of N2O to the iron atoms in the framework, thereby leading to an improvement in the oxidizing process. Furthermore, the reaction pathways for the new structures show reduced enthalpy barrier in the rate-detg. step in the oxidn. of ethane reaction cycle compared to the original Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74. These findings provide ways in which the performance of the Fe0.1Mg1.9-MOF-74 can be optimized for next-generation catalysts.
